key_points: Gaige Grosskreutz, the lone survivor shot by Kyle Rittenhouse, admitted to unholstering his gun and pointing it at Rittenhouse before being shot.
Grosskreutz, a trained paramedic, testified he was not intending to kill Rittenhouse but was trying to preserve his own life.
His testimony appeared to bolster Rittenhouse's self-defense claim, acknowledging he believed Rittenhouse was being chased with intent to harm.
Grosskreutz organized a medical corps at protests and was carrying a gun and providing first aid during the Kenosha protests.
Unlike Rittenhouse, Grosskreutz obtained his firearm through proper channels and was certified as an EMT.
Grosskreutz did not consider himself to be participating in the protests but was there in a medical and protective capacity.
He accused Rittenhouse of 'murdering' another individual, Anthony Huber, but the judge instructed the jury to disregard the comment.
Grosskreutz's testimony revealed he might have unintentionally pointed his gun at Rittenhouse.
He underwent several surgeries after the shooting, losing sensation below the elbow of the injured arm.
Grosskreutz filed a $10 million lawsuit against Kenosha law enforcement, claiming they shared blame for Rittenhouse's actions.
